item.title: Creating a New Theme
item.description: Introduction # This tutorial will show you how to create a simple theme in Hugo. I assume that you are familiar with HTML, the bash command line, and that you are comfortable using Markdown to format content. I’ll explain how Hugo uses templates and how you can organize your templates to create a theme. I won’t cover using CSS to style your theme. We’ll start with creating a new site with a very basic template.

item.title: Migrate to Hugo from Jekyll
item.description: Move static content to static # Jekyll has a rule that any directory not starting with _ will be copied as-is to the _site output. Hugo keeps all static content under static. You should therefore move it all there. With Jekyll, something that looked like ▾ <root>/ ▾ images/ logo.png should become ▾ <root>/ ▾ static/ ▾ images/ logo.png Additionally, you’ll want any files that should reside at the root (such as CNAME) to be moved to static.

item.title: (Hu)go Template Primer
item.description: Hugo uses the excellent Go html/template library for its template engine. It is an extremely lightweight engine that provides a very small amount of logic. In our experience that it is just the right amount of logic to be able to create a good static website. If you have used other template systems from different languages or frameworks you will find a lot of similarities in Go templates. This document is a brief primer on using Go templates.

item.title: Getting Started with Hugo
item.description: Step 1. Install Hugo # Go to Hugo releases and download the appropriate version for your OS and architecture. Save it somewhere specific as we will be using it in the next step. More complete instructions are available at Install Hugo Step 2. Build the Docs # Hugo has its own example site which happens to also be the documentation site you are reading right now. Follow the following steps:

Get Involved # Getting started # The History of HackUNT It’s not required to know the history of HackUNT to get involved in it; nevertheless, it will give you perspective on where we started and where we are going. HackUNT History How to get involved # New Member I’m new… now what? # Read the documentation on your role in the HackUNT/roles/ section Coordinate with the president about what is needed from you Attend the meetings Have fun, and joy the experience!

Git Workflows # Setting up git on your system # MacOS MacOS # This is tab MacOS content. Lorem markdownum insigne. Olympo signis Delphis! Retexi Nereius nova develat stringit, frustra Saturnius uteroque inter! Oculis non ritibus Telethusa protulit, sed sed aere valvis inhaesuro Pallas animam: qui quid, ignes. Miseratus fonte Ditis conubia. Linux Linux # This is tab Linux content. Lorem markdownum insigne. Olympo signis Delphis! Retexi Nereius nova develat stringit, frustra Saturnius uteroque inter!

4th Level of Menu # Caesorum illa tu sentit micat vestes papyriferi # Inde aderam facti; Theseus vis de tauri illa peream. Oculos uberaque non regisque vobis cursuque, opus venit quam vulnera. Buttons # Buttons are styled links that can lead to local page or external link. Buttons Example # {{< button relref="/" [class="..."] >}}Get Home{{< /button >}} {{< button href="https://github.com/alex-shpak/hugo-book" >}}Contribute{{< /button >}} Get Home Contribute Columns # Columns help organize shorter pieces of content horizontally for readability. {{< columns >}} <!-- begin columns block --> # Left Content Lorem markdownum insigne... <---> <!-- magic separator, between columns --> # Mid Content Lorem markdownum insigne.

HackUNT Checklist # This checklist is everything I can remember that needs to be done to make HackUNT possible. This list is not in order it is just everything I can remember and will be added to as needed. Hack UNT Operations # Typeform Set up for Registration Pick a theme for the event Make Sponsor Packet ( Use Canva ) Make Sponsor Onboarding Packet Pick a date for the event Set up the event on Org Sync ( you will need to keep up with this and answer their comments.

Day Of Actions # Check-in Station ( 2 - 3 People ) # This person will be in charge of getting Check-in operational on the day of the event. Checking with Volunteers, Hackers, and Sponsors when arriving. Be sure to be kind and understanding if there is an issue feel free to let ( Andy / Nick ) know so we can mitigate any fallout. Check-in List Hacker Hacker Badge Writing names on badges Team Name If they do not have a team don’t worry just remind them about the team matching channel in Discord and our Team Matching Event.
Event WiFi # Event WiFi is supplied by the UNT IT department.

Design Team # Phase 1 # Create and finalize logo Create and finalize brand Make brand guidelines Make event flyers Make sticker design Make badge design Make volunteer promotion flyer Make Website mockup Make Livesite mockup Phase 2 # Get Speaker schedule from external relations Make speaker infographic Get judge panel and make bios from external relations Get Staff bios Get Tech Sponsors Get food sponsors from external relations Get Registration time Get prizes Phase 3 # Make event map with president Make T-Shirt design Make guide book template Collaborate and finalize the 5 guidebooks (sponsors, attendees, volunteers, mentors, and hackers) with the president Continuous # Make 20 social media posts Post other Hackathons on social media Post on Facebook, Instagram, and Snapchat each week 5 bio posts 2-3 registration posts 2-3 speaker posts 2-3 food posts 1 prize post 1 volunteer post 2-3 sponsor posts

External Relations # Find and Finalize 5 judges Reach out to 10 potential mentors a week Create a workshop schedule Find 10-20 workshop speakers Contact 10 tech sponsors a week Contact 2 food sponsors a week/get quotes Get T-Shirt quotes Get Sticker sponsor Get Badge quotes Contact News Sources

President # Phase 1 # Finalize Date Find and Finalize Venue Find and Finalize Tables, Chairs, and Cords Find and Finalize Internet Find and Finalize Power Create initial Budget Sheet Phase 2 # Talk to CSCE about collaborating Sponsorship Mentors Volunteers Talk to the College of Engineering Sponsorship Mentors Volunteers Talk to UIS about collaborating Sponsorship Talk to DAIR about collaborating Sponsorship Talk to the President about collaborating Sponsorship Phase 3 # Collaborate with the brand director to make an event map Innovate and check on other processes

Email Templates # Following up # We should follow up with sponsors after our event. It is important to know what we did right and did wrong. This will better help us to understand the wants and needs of our sponsors. These companies were willing to give us a chance and give us a considerable amount. It is important that we try to mitigate all damages that might have occurred during the event.
Initial Outreach #

Onboarding # Sponsorship Onboarding is the next step after sponsors agree to participate in the hackathon! It is very important that you follow up quickly and respectively during these times. Sponsors will have quite a few questions but most can be answered by giving them the Sponsor Onboarding Packet.

Sponsorhip Retrospective # Following up # We should follow up with sponsors after our event. It is important to know what we did right and did wrong. This will better help us to understand the wants and needs of our sponsors. These companies were willing to give us a chance and give us a considerable amount. It is important that we try to mitigate all damages that might have occurred during the event.

Stats # Stats must be updated yearly It’s best to update the yearly stats as soon as possible, and or after the hackathon. Yearly Registration/Attendess Stats # Year Registration Attendess Ratio 2018 ? 248 N/A 2019 498 258 51.81% 2020 558 220 39.43% 2021 ? ? N/A 2022 ? ? N/A Yearly Marketing Totals Stats # Year Ongoing Resumes Projects Attendess Prizes awarded 2018 1 ? ? ? ? 2019 2 250+ 192+ 200+ $56,900+ 2020 3 ?

Volunteer Guidelines # Pre-Event or Pre-Shift # Familiarize self with Event Action Plan Have knowledge of severe weather safety areas at Discovery Park 1st floor Identify: Fire Extinguisher locations Automated External Defibrillators ( used to treat sudden cardiac arrest) Manual Fire Alarm Pull Stations at exits First Aid Kits During Event # Report to your section and let the previous volunteers/organizers know you are there for the shift. Ensure all guests associated with Hackathon have correct credentials ( badge, shirt, etc.
